prompt:
Let’s go one step at a time. Wait for me before moving on to
  the next part.
Only give me step 1. Don’t move to step 2 unless I say so.

Help me think through this — don’t solve it all at once. Walk
  through your reasoning with me slowly.

Break this into manageable parts. Let’s work on just the first
  one.

Don’t write long replies. Keep it to one actionable thought at
  a time.

Give me the answer as 5–7 concise bullet points. No long
  paragraphs.
Reply to each question like a tweet: under 280 characters.

Break this concept into learning chunks. Give me the first one
  and ask if I want to continue.

Feed me this information in a slow drip — one concept per
  message. Ask before sending the next.

Ask me guiding questions instead of giving answers. Help me
  arrive at the insight myself.

I want to quiz *you*. Respond only with short answers I can
  build on or correct.

Teach this back to me as if I’m a beginner and ask for
  confirmation after each section.

After each answer, ask: “Do you want to continue?” Don’t
  assume I do.

Start by giving me a simple diagram, emoji flow, or ASCII
  sketch — then explain if I ask.

Explain this using one analogy. Wait for my response before
  giving another.

Assume I need time to digest. Keep things extremely simple and
  spaced out.

Summarize all insights rapidly in one burst. I’ll slow you
  down if needed.

Present your answer as a mental map: core topic, branches,
  sub-branches — and wait for me to pick one.

After explaining something, ask: “Was that clear or should I
  reword it?”

If I reply with “pause,” stop immediately and wait for further
  instruction — no summarizing.

Before you answer, summarize what you believe I’m trying to
  accomplish in one sentence.

Reflect my request back to me in 3–5 bullet points before you
  proceed.

Tell me what you think my ultimate goal is here, based on my
  message.

If you’re unsure about what I want, ask a clarifying question
  before answering.

List 2–3 possible interpretations of my request, then ask
  which one I meant.

Explain how you’re interpreting my prompt before you generate
  any output.
Based on what I said, what do you think my main priority is?
Tell me what assumptions you're making about my request.
Restate my request as if you're briefing a colleague.
What do you think the first principles behind my request are?

Reflect my message back using the same tone and language I
  used.

Based on this and past chats, what do you think I really want
  to achieve?

Break down my prompt into its components and say what each
  part means to you.

If any part of my message is unclear, flag it instead of
  guessing.

First rephrase my prompt clearly in your own words — then
  respond.
Mirror my goals and desired outcome as you understand them.

List any critical information you need before giving a strong
  answer.

After answering, rate your confidence in having interpreted my
  request correctly.
Ask me two clarifying questions before generating a response.

Rate how sure you are about what I’m asking on a scale of 1–10
  — then answer.

Format your response so I can copy and paste it directly into
  a document or email with no cleanup needed.
Only respond using bullet points — no paragraphs or intros.

Structure your response so it’s easily scannable — short
  sections, bolded headers, and spacing.

Write your answer as if it's going into a client presentation.
  Clear, clean, and professionally polished.

Strip out all emojis, filler words, and casual fluff. Just the
  content.

Respond using plain text with no formatting, Markdown, or
  symbols.

Rephrase everything using plain, simple, everyday language a
  6th grader would understand.

Give me a sharp, concise executive summary with optional
  expansion if I ask.

Write this in a punchy, Twitter thread format. Number each
  point.

Format your answer as a ready-to-send email, including subject
  line and greeting.

Present your answer in a clean table with headers and concise
  rows.

Use headings to group ideas, and bullets underneath — no full
  paragraphs.

Format your output as a to-do list or checklist I can act on
  immediately.

Write this as content for slides — no full sentences, just
  phrases and talking points.

Write this as if it’s going into a Google Doc. Clean, properly
  styled sections.

Include layout suggestions like alignment, spacing, or
  formatting if this was for a webpage.

Avoid all styling — no bold, italics, caps, or Markdown. Just
  raw, readable text.

Format your answer so it's ultra readable on a small screen —
  short lines and tight structure.

Format with one sentence per line for clarity — no long
  paragraphs.

Design your output for a clean, print-ready document. Include
  headings, whitespace, and no clutter.

Give me 3 completely different business ideas based on this
  prompt — they should serve different industries or customer types.

Suggest startup ideas across 3 very different fields (e.g.
  health, logistics, education) based on my input.

Propose one business idea that sounds bizarre or
  unconventional — then explain how it could actually work.

Give me one obvious business model and one totally unexpected
  twist on it.

Suggest a playful or novelty-style business idea related to
  this theme.

Describe this business idea as if you’re explaining it to a
  7-year-old.

Give me 5 'bad' startup ideas that might actually have some
  hidden genius to them.

List 5 wild-card business ideas that no one is talking about,
  even if they sound strange.

Imagine a world where everything is reversed — how would a
  business based on my idea work there?

Explain this business concept using analogies from a zoo, a
  restaurant, and a spaceship.

Turn this business idea into a meme-worthy product or service.
  Describe the image + tagline.

Pitch this business idea in a rhyming, playful Dr. Seuss
  style.

Pitch this startup as if you were a pirate, Shakespeare, or a
  Hollywood villain.

Take a cheesy joke or pun and turn it into an actual business
  idea.

Turn this idea into an animated product or service concept —
  describe the story and use.

Mash up two unrelated industries (e.g. yoga + welding) into
  one surprising business concept.

Invent a business idea that works using backwards logic. Then
  justify why it might succeed.

Imagine aliens launching this business on Earth — how would
  they pitch it to humans?

Create a business idea that completely breaks industry rules
  or norms.

Turn this business idea into a jingle or theme song. Include
  at least one rhyme.

Design a prompt that asks for tactics, not facts — like a
  strategist, not a search engine.

Add odd rules or boundaries to this prompt to push out
  creative answers.

Break this into prompt stages — discovery, refinement, and
  execution.
Write a reusable prompt that helps improve any other prompt.

Add 3 types of reference data to improve this prompt (text,
  image, schema).
Turn a vague goal into a clear, actionable prompt.

Draft a system message to use as the base config for a new
  GPT.

Shrink this prompt to be reusable in an API call or embedded
  workflow.

Make the response use metaphors from music, sports, and
  nature.

Have the model respond in the voice of a niche expert or
  public figure.
Rewrite the prompt to walk me to the answer through questions.

Before prompting, generate a map of all the inputs I should
  gather.
Make this prompt balance humor and analytical clarity.

Turn this into a prompt template with variables like
  {{topic}}, {{tone}}, etc.

Format the prompt output to return structured JSON for API
  consumption.
Make this prompt multilingual but keep all outputs in English.

Add dummy data to the prompt so the model can reason from
  examples.

Add irrelevant or noisy info and test if the prompt still
  works.

Start the prompt with an explanation, then give the goal, then
  clarify output format.

Refactor the prompt to work well even with vague or weak user
  inputs.

Map out the full system architecture needed to support this
  app.
Define the user roles, access levels, and permission logic.
Break the backend into clearly separated services or modules.

Add event listeners or triggers where logic needs to react to
  user inputs.

Write a schema that supports full CRUD operations for this
  app.
List how each database table relates to the others.
Format this for quick launch inside Supabase or Firebase.
Split read-heavy and write-heavy logic in the architecture.

List what data or assets should be preloaded to speed things
  up.

Make the app work with no user login — how would that change
  the build?
Make this architecture work offline or with partial sync.
Redesign the data model to store only the bare minimum needed.

Make this architecture work well on edge compute or CDN-first
  platforms.
Optimize the backend to serve low-bandwidth mobile clients.
Break logic into deployable functions with clear triggers.
Create a mock seed file with sample data for dev preview.

Structure this for one-click deploy via Vercel, Netlify, or
  Fly.

Add all necessary security measures: auth, validation, rate
  limits.
What’s the leanest possible infra setup that still works?

Convert this schema into a prompt usable by ChatGPT or other
  LLM.
Simulate where this code might break and suggest 3 fixes.
Translate confusing error logs into human-readable guidance.
List 3 possible causes before running any fix.
Write a test to force this system to break — then explain why.

Refactor this problem to isolate it into a smaller failing
  unit.
Write a retrospective for a bug that slipped into prod.
Add rollback logic or failovers to the vulnerable parts.
Explain how app state might be causing hidden errors.

What questions should I be asking before assuming the code is
  wrong?

Turn this error message into a probable fix ranked by
  likelihood.
List quick ways to debug frontend/backend sync issues.
Check for dependency or library mismatches silently failing.

Build a retry system that handles flaky connections
  gracefully.

Write a quick script to check if DB values are what they
  should be.

What kind of silent fails might be happening — and how to
  catch them?
At what point do I roll back vs. patching forward?
Could this be a browser-based rendering bug? Explain why.
Scan my imports and highlight ones that are often unstable.

Make this feature fail-safe — users should never get a crash
  screen.

Give me a GPT prompt to generate a hotfix-only version of this
  feature.
Redesign this interaction to happen in a single click.
Make sure every screen or state gives the user a next step.
Write short, punchy copy for this UI element.
Redesign the empty state to feel helpful, not sad.
Add one fun, unexpected UX detail to this flow.
Link user input directly to a fast, visible action.
Remove or rethink steps that create unnecessary friction.
Adapt this UI for thumb-driven mobile behavior.
Improve this form to feel lighter or more playful.

Design a small but rewarding moment when a user completes
  this.
Give me 3 clever loading states with branding.
Reword this to add soft urgency without being annoying.
Suggest icons that convey this action visually.
Reorder UI elements based on what should grab attention first.
Hide advanced settings behind a ‘Show More’ flow.
Add animation to signal this state transition clearly.

What about this UI might fail for vision or screen reader
  users?
Write UI copy that sets the vibe for the product.
Design this flow to allow easy undo of accidental actions.
Add just-in-time tooltips to boost clarity without clutter.
Brainstorm a viral growth idea that costs $0 to launch.
Add a social sharing mechanic that feels like a reward.
Make this offer feel urgent or limited — tactfully.
Design a free-to-premium journey that feels natural.
Create a low-effort, long-tail SEO content idea.
Invent a use case for this tool the creators didn’t plan.
Make this product sticky by tying it to a daily habit.
Trigger marketing events from user behavior inside the app.
Streamline the first session so users get to value faster.
Design a referral program that feels valuable to both parties.
Make part of the product output easy to share by default.
Redesign the UX to give users early dopamine hits.
Design a feature users want to screenshot and post elsewhere.
Pitch a weird or bold headline that makes this go viral.
Add growth mechanics without shady behavior or dark patterns.
Embed email capture in a non-intrusive, high-converting way.
Trigger follow-up emails or nudges from user events.
Design a small campaign that leverages creator audiences.

Craft a prompt to create buzz for a product that’s not ready
  yet.
Add a moment where users can flex their results.
Redesign the product assuming the AI is the core interface.
Let users preview how prompts will behave before running.
Use past user activity to auto-fill prompt inputs.
Keep a transparent history of AI inputs/outputs.
Let users set the vibe or rules for the AI’s tone.
Use AI to infer setup steps so users skip config.

Add retrieval-based memory so the model pulls in up-to-date
  info.

Let users name and customize a persona to respond
  in-character.
Store project context so AI replies feel consistent.
Have the AI rate how sure it is in its response.
Let the AI act as live documentation during setup.
Build an AI-powered command bar to trigger tasks.
Use AI to guess the next action the user might take.
Auto-describe error messages in plain language.
Simulate how two or more agents might collaborate.
Use user behavior to trigger AI without needing prompts.
Use AI to auto-label content or classify user inputs.
Design the app to support voice AI use cases.
Use AI as a backup when normal logic fails.
Build an AI feature that’s always on — but never in the way.
Test 5 versions of this UI copy or layout in under 5 minutes.
Give me 2 versions of this prompt and simulate which one wins.
Predict what feedback I’d get if 10 users saw this feature.
Describe the MVP in detail — no code, just flow.
Summarize this feature in dev-ready bullet points.

Simulate a toggle that switches core functionality — does it
  break anything?
Intentionally break a flow and see how it degrades.
Summarize what’s changed across last 3 iterations.
Roleplay a feedback loop with a pretend user.
Add an easy way for users to rate or flag something.
After each build, list 5 things most likely to go wrong.
Write a one-line testable hypothesis for this feature.
How easy is it to back out of this feature cleanly?

Remove all visual cues and test if users can still complete
  the task.

Does this product feel delightful or annoying? Rate and
  explain.
What’s the riskiest assumption here — and how do I test it?

What’s the smallest thing I could ship right now to validate
  the idea?
Give me 3 survey questions to test this feature with users.
Turn this iteration into a shareable devlog or Twitter thread.
Auto-generate test cases from this feature spec.

Summarize this lecture/textbook chapter into 5 key takeaways a
  classmate could memorize.

Create a study plan for this course with daily targets leading
  up to the exam.

Turn this topic into a memory palace I can visualize and walk
  through.

Generate 10 spaced-repetition-style flashcards for this
  subject.

Ask me 5 quiz questions from this topic with increasing
  difficulty.

Teach this concept so a 10-year-old could understand and
  repeat it.

Design a Pomodoro-style session with 4 focused blocks and
  break prompts.

Use analogies from sports or pop culture to explain this
  subject.
Rewrite this idea in a short, sticky sentence I won’t forget.

Describe a visual mind map for this topic, including branches
  and labels.

Compare long-term studying with cramming for this topic — pros
  and cons.

Give me a format to teach this to a friend and check for
  understanding.
What are common mistakes students make on this topic in exams?
Condense this topic into a one-pager, broken into headers.
Summarize this topic as a short rhyme or jingle.

Link facts in this topic to a theme like 'space' or 'jungle'
  to remember them.

Explain this idea 3 different ways: visual, verbal, and
  story-based.

How would I view this topic before learning it vs. after
  understanding it?
Compress this topic into a 100-word tweetstorm.

Write a back-and-forth mock convo with a classmate reviewing
  this.

Build me a full outline for an argumentative essay on this
  topic.

List 5 useful sources or types of evidence I could include for
  this assignment.

Rewrite this thesis statement to be clearer, punchier, and
  more debatable.
What are 2 strong counterpoints I should include and refute?
Review this structure and suggest a better logical flow.
Write an opening sentence that would hook my professor.

Give me 5 different sentence openers for analytical
  paragraphs.
Make this conclusion sound confident and reflective.
Rewrite this section using active voice to sound stronger.

Give me a checklist for properly citing references in APA or
  MLA.
Delete any vague filler from this intro and make it sharper.
Test if each paragraph has a clear, relevant topic sentence.
Generate 5 short, relevant quotes I could use in my essay.
Match the tone of this paragraph to sound more academic.
Make this writing sound like it came from a published paper.
Add 150 words of useful elaboration to this argument.
Write a stat or question that could act as a compelling hook.

Simplify any academic jargon in this draft so it’s easier to
  read.
Grade this essay and explain your feedback like a lecturer.
Give me a polished version of this that’s ready to turn in.

Help me time-block my week for class, study, sleep, and
  sanity.
Sort my tasks into urgent, medium, and long-term priorities.

Plan my next 7 days based on upcoming uni, work, and
  deadlines.

Add break time, sleep buffers, and motivation rituals to this
  schedule.
Give me a setup to eliminate procrastination triggers.
Help me prep my to-do list the night before each day.
Turn these goals into repeatable systems instead.
I have too much due — help me triage what to focus on.
Design a 90-minute deep focus window for tackling uni work.
What should I do when I feel guilty for not being productive?
What’s a good system for resetting after falling behind?
Give me a bird’s eye view of my semester layout.
It’s week 6 and I haven’t started — how do I catch up?
Help me unload and organize everything that’s weighing on me.

Help me notice which times of day are best for different
  tasks.
Diagnose what’s draining my motivation and how to reboot it.
Build a simple, sustainable weekly routine I can stick to.
Break this assignment into 5 timed chunks with milestones.
Design a 48-hour study sprint for an upcoming test.
Help me finish this in half the time I think it will take.
Find 5 high-quality, credible sources for this research topic.
Refine this research question to be more focused and testable.

Outline the key themes and debates I should cover in a
  literature review.

What research gaps or underexplored areas can I build on in
  this topic?
Give me a guide for searching academic databases effectively.
Suggest Boolean search strings for this topic.
Format these citations in APA, MLA, or Chicago style.
Where can I find public datasets related to this topic?
How do I get the best results from Google Scholar for this?

Give me best practices for writing student-friendly survey
  questions.
Classify these sources as primary or secondary and why.

Evaluate the credibility of this source using CRAAP or another
  method.

What are the typical steps for completing a full research
  project?
Translate peer-reviewed article findings into plain English.
What ethical considerations apply to this research plan?

Map out a timeline with realistic milestones for this
  research.
Create a system to track my sources and notes for later use.

Help me decide which parts to quote vs paraphrase in this
  text.

Write a short annotation for this article explaining its
  relevance.
How has thinking on this topic changed over the past 10 years?

Rewrite this bullet point to sound sharper and more
  results-focused.
Write a strong, attention-grabbing first paragraph.
Match my resume to the key skills in this job ad.

Help me write a STAR-format answer for this interview
  question.
Polish this LinkedIn summary to sound confident and authentic.

Write a 30-second elevator pitch for me based on this
  experience.

Identify transferable skills from my part-time job or uni
  projects.

What questions should I prepare for this specific role or
  company?
Write a short, professional DM to a recruiter on LinkedIn.

Which of these projects should I include in my portfolio — and
  why?
Create a weekly routine for job hunting while at uni.
Write a professional follow-up email after an interview.

Ask me questions that reveal what industries or roles I’d
  enjoy.
Help me define the kind of culture and values I want in a job.
What should I expect or prepare for in my first internship?

Give me a strategy for finding remote or flexible student
  jobs.
List AI tools that could help me get hired or build my brand.

How would I interview someone else for this job — what would I
  ask?

Write a list of achievements I can reuse in resumes and
  interviews.
Give me a layout for a student portfolio site.
Suggest how to assign roles based on different working styles.
How can I handle a group member who isn’t contributing?
Write a first meeting agenda for a new group project.

What tools or templates should we use for smoother
  collaboration?

Break the group assignment into weekly deadlines and
  checkpoints.
Draft a basic team agreement with rules for communication.
How should we respond if someone misses a milestone?
How do I give peer feedback constructively and clearly?
Design a presentation flow where each group member speaks.
How can we ensure fair credit for each person’s contribution?
Visualize each person’s tasks over the course of the project.
What’s our contingency plan if someone drops out last minute?
Suggest weekly check-in questions that keep momentum.
Write a quick recap email after our team meeting.
Help me assess my groupmates fairly using a rubric.
How do we include a shy or quiet member meaningfully?
Propose a system for making decisions when we disagree.
Design a simple prompt we can post weekly for updates.
Write 3 gentle nudges to use if someone’s falling behind.
Suggest a way to celebrate a team win at the end.
Give me a 5-slide layout to present this topic effectively.

Write a compelling first sentence to grab the room’s
  attention.

Estimate how long it would take to read this presentation
  aloud.
Suggest 5 ideas for visuals, metaphors, or props I could use.
Write a confident, clear final sentence to end my talk.
Write speaker notes that explain what to say on each slide.
Turn these bullet points into a smooth story flow.
Give me tips for reducing nerves during a live presentation.
What should I double-check before presenting in class?
Give me a short version I could use if I run out of time.
What should I ask classmates to focus on when giving feedback?
Make these slide titles clearer and more engaging.
Would this topic work better as slides or a one-pager?
Suggest a small demo or interaction to add energy.
What’s one trick to improve eye contact while presenting?
Help me cut filler words like 'um' or 'like' from my speech.
Predict 3 possible questions I could get and how to answer.
Write a few journaling prompts to help me reflect after.
What design principles will make my slides look clean?
How memorable is this pitch? Suggest one thing to improve.
Give me 5 niche markets with low competition and high passion.
Take a popular trend and twist it into a new business angle.

What are people complaining about in forums that I could build
  around?

Apply the business model of X to industry Y — what’s the
  mashup?
Based on these constraints, what side hustle ideas fit best?

What business could I build around my biggest obsession or
  curiosity?
Stack 2 ideas I like into one unexpected business concept.
What recurring pain point in my life could become a business?

Start with a cool product — what kind of business could it
  power?

If I wanted to quit my job in 12 months, what business path
  would I pick?

What business could I run if I had no internet for half the
  day?
What could I sell to a small, specific group of 500 people?
What business could win just in my town or region?
Give me a business that sells to businesses, not consumers.
Take a boring offline service and SaaS-ify it.
What idea could I spin up in 72 hours from zero?

What can I rebundle (or unbundle) to offer more value or

Turn this hobby into a viable business path.

Based on what I already have (time, skills, tools), what
  should I build?

Pick one tool (e.g. Notion, AI, Shopify) — what niche product

What are the biggest red flags about this idea that could kill

How would a customer find this business from a standing start?
